What do we mean by "encoding"?
What is a text ? what is a document ?
What can we do with XML ?

div.head: Digitization and encoding
div.p: We expect more and more of the digital objects we produce ...

list.item: surrogate representations of original documents
descriptions of such representations ("metadata")
integrated collections of such representations and their metadata (the "digital edition")
support for increasingly complex searching and analysis across such collections

div.p: And increasingly we want to share these digital resources in new and unexpected ways

div.head: Maybe the TEI can help ...
div.p:
The TEI (of which more anon) provides a well established conceptual model of text able to support:
conversion od existing data
creation of new datasets
integration of existing data sets deriuved from a variety of sources
It is an open and non proprietary format, based on open technologies
It also expresses an explicit theory about textual ontology

div.head: Are these images of the same thing?
Are these images of the same thing?
A text is not a document
div.p:
What is the essential part of a text?
in the shape of letters and their layout?
in the original from which this copy derives?
in the stories we read into it? or in its author's intentions?
A "document" is something that exists in the world, which we can digitize.
A "text" is an abstraction, created by or for a community of readers, which we can encode.

div.head: What do we do when we digitize?

list.item: A text is more than a sequence of encoded glyphs or characters!

A text is more than a sequence of lexical forms!
It has a structure and a communicative function
It also has multiple possible readings
its meaning can be enriched by annotation
Encoding, or markup, is a way of making these things explicit
Only that which is explicit can be reliably processed

div.head: The Babel effect
div.p: Naturally, there are many possible readings of most texts ...
... and (alas) many different ways of expressing each reading!

list.item: Good news : there is software capable of converting amongst hundreds of different formats
Bad news : we still need it

figure.head: without a standard interchange format: 20 translations are needed for 5 formats (n*n-n)
with a standard interchange format: 10 translations are needed for 5 formats (n*2)

list.item: Encoding is a way of making explicit the important distinctions identified in a text
Hence, it is a way of identifying and naming the components of a textual structure in a formal manner
What kinds of component are significant? This will depend on our intended usage...

div.head: Separation of form and content
div.p:
It is a very very old argument (going back to Aristotle), but in general
descriptive encoding (such as the TEI) which focus on the content rather than the form is to be preferred
if only because it makes it easier to re-use the same content for many purposes
and because content seems somehow less dispensable than form

div.head: The encoding language we use must be able to ...

list.item: specify all the characters found in a document
make explicit the structures perceived in a text
represent that structure in a linear processable form
supply a variety of metadata: additional information about the document and the text.

div.p: Which specific components from this list we need will vary depending on the goal of our project, but the TEI is based on the belief that we can agree on a useful inventory

div.head: XML: what it is and why you should care

list.item: XML is structured data represented as strings of text

XML looks like HTML, except that:-
XML is extensible
XML must be well-formed
XML can be validated
XML is application-, platform-, and vendor- independent
XML empowers the content provider and facilitates data integration

div.head: (Nearly) all you need to know about XML, on one slide

list.item: An XML document contains at least one named element
The start of each element occurrence is indicated by a start-tag, and its end by an end-tag; in between there may (or may not) be some content
An element may also have some attributes, each of which has a name and a value
An XML document must be well formed i.e. it must conform to the syntax of XML
A well-formed XML document may optionally be valid i.e. il may conform to some additional rules defined in some particular schema

div.head: A sample XML document
div.eg: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <cookBook> <recipe n="1"> <head>Stone soup</head> <ingredientList> <ingredient>an onion</ingredient> <ingredient>two carrots</ingredient> <ingredient>some water</ingredient> ... <ingredient>a magic stone</ingredient> <ingredient>some naive peasants</ingredient> </ingredientList> <procedure> <step>put the water to boil in a big cauldron</step> <step>add the other ingredients</step> .... <step>take out the stone and serve</step> </procedure> </recipe> <recipe n="2"> <!-- second recipe here --> </recipe> <!-- hic desunt multa --> </cookBook>

div.head: XML syntax
div.p:
An XML document contains :-
Unicode characters
elements, with optional attributes
comments
processing instructions
entity references (internal ou external)
CDATA marked sections
That's all !

list.item: An XML document actually represents a tree composed of nodes
There is one root node which contains all the others

Each node can contain
a (sub)tree
an element with optional attributes
a string of characters (text)

A subtree can contain
a mixture of elements and text (mixed content)
elements only (element content)
Each element has a name a generic identifier
Each attribute has a name and a value
Names are associatred with a namespace
An XML document is encoded as a linear string of Unicode characters
It begins with a special processing instruction
Each element occurrence within it is marked by a start- and an end-tags.
Attribute name/value pairs are supplied on the start-tag and may be given in any order
The characters < and & are Magic and must always be "escaped" if you want to use them as themselves
The namespace to which an element belongs may be indicated by means of a predefined namespace prefix e.g. xml:
Comments are delimited by <!- - and - ->
Entity references are delimited by & and ;
CDATA sections are delimited by <![CDATA[ and ]]>

div.head: XML syntax: the small print
div.p: What does it mean for a document to be well-formed?

list.item: there is a single root node containing the whole of it
each subtree is properly nested within the root node
names are always case sensitive
start-tags and end-tags are always mandatory (except that a combined start-and-end tag may be used for empty nodes)
attribute values are always quoted

div.head: XML is an international standard

list.item:
An XML document must respect ISO standard ISO 10646 (aka Unicode)
un repertoire de caractères 31-bit adequate à la plupart des systèmes d'ecriture humaine
encode en deux formats UTF8 ou UTF16
un document peut specifier qu'il contient les mêmes caractères encodes d'une autre manière (notamment ISO 8859)
un element peut specifier le langage de sa contenue avec l'attribut predefini xml:lang

div.p: L'attribut xml:id est egalement predefini par le W3C.

div.head: XML validation
div.p: A valid XML document is well formed, and also conforms to some additional rules, which make up what we call a schema.

A schema allows you to specify:
which elements can appear as the root element of a document
which elements and attributes can appear where
names, datatypes, and default values for all attributes
A schema thus allows you to check that every chapter must begin with a heading or recipes must include an ingredient list
A namespace by contrast just allows you to label elements as being somehow related. A schema provides a formal specification and is written in a formal language

div.head: Schema languages
div.p:
A schema can be expressed using:
DTD: an older ISO standard
RNG: ISO standard RELAXNG
WSD: the W3C Schema language
All have different tool kits, different syntaxes, and different methods of doing things, particularly for content validation.
The TEI uses RELAXNG
